1. POLICY & GOVERNANCE LAYER
────────────────────────────────
• Treasury Risk Policy (Board-approved)

• Core systems

Tutorial: From Idea to Income – How to Create and Sell Software Products

0. Mind-set first  
   • Treat software as a product business, not a one-off project.  
   • Expect multiple iterations, feedback loops and ongoing support.  
   • Aim for “minimum lovable product” (MLP) rather than perfect v1.0.

1. Pick a profitable problem  
   a. Brainstorm domains you know (work, hobbies, industry pain points).  
   b. Collect evidence of pain: forum complaints, SaaS review sites, sub-Reddits, job ads that list repetitive tasks, “spreadsheet hell” stories, etc.  
   c. Validate willingness to pay: quick survey, pre-order page, or paid pilot consulting.  
   d. Check market size and price tolerance: B2B niches often support higher ARPU; B2C needs large volumes or subscription upsell.  

2. Translate problem → product concept  
   • Write a concise value proposition: “X for Y that solves Z.”  
   • List must-have vs nice-to-have features (MoSCoW or Kano method).  
   • Sketch user flow or low-fidelity wireframes; test them with 5–10 target users.  
   • Confirm competitive advantage: speed, UI/UX, integrations, pricing, brand.

3. Plan architecture and tech stack  
   • Match stack to problem and skills: SaaS? desktop? mobile? browser extension?  
   • Weigh build speed vs long-term maintainability.  
   • Embrace off-the-shelf building blocks: authentication (Auth0), payments (Stripe), hosting (Vercel, AWS Amplify), UI kits.  
   • Establish version control (Git), issue tracking and CI/CD from day one.

4. Develop your Minimum Lovable Product  
   • Code to learning goals, not to spec perfection.  
   • Automate tests around core value (unit + end-to-end).  
   • Instrument analytics (Mixpanel/Amplitude/PostHog) to capture usage data.  
   • Ship in small increments behind feature flags.  
   • Keep technical debt log; schedule refactor checkpoints every release cycle.

5. Price and package  
   • Common models:  
     – Freemium → paid tiers (SaaS)  
     – One-time license + optional maintenance (desktop/mobile)  
     – Usage-based (API/SaaS)  
   • Anchor to ROI, not cost-plus. If you save a company $1 000/month, $100–$200/mo is fair.  
   • Offer annual plans at 2 × monthly price for cash flow.  
   • Define feature gates per tier; reserve high-value integrations/reporting for higher tiers.

6. Handle legal & compliance early  
   • Pick license (proprietary, dual GPL/commercial, etc.).  
   • Create Terms of Service, Privacy Policy, DPA (use generators + lawyer review).  
   • Comply with data regulations (GDPR/CCPA).  
   • Register business entity and handle tax (VAT, sales tax via Paddle/Stripe Tax).  
   • Protect IP (copyright notices, optionally trademarks).

7. Go-to-market strategy  
   a. Audience building (before launch)  
      – Publish problem/solution content (blog, Twitter, LinkedIn, TikTok demos).  
      – Share build-in-public milestones.  
      – Collect wait-list emails.  
   b. Launch sequence  
      – Private beta → invite list (collect testimonials).  
      – Public launch on Product Hunt, Hacker News, Reddit niche, indie hacker podcasts.  
      – Retarget website visitors with lightweight remarketing ads.  
   c. Sales channels  
      B2C: App Stores, marketplaces (Chrome Web Store, Shopify Apps, WordPress plugins).  
      B2B: inbound content + outbound email/LinkedIn, partner/reseller programs, affiliate links.  

8. Onboarding & retention  
   • Provide zero-friction signup (OAuth, password-less).  
   • Guide first-run experience: checklist, sample data, interactive tour.  
   • Trigger lifecycle emails at “aha moments” and inactivity points.  
   • Offer chat support or community Slack/Discord.  
   • Monitor churn reasons; build product/educational fixes.  

9. Support, feedback and iteration  
   • Instrument feedback widgets (Canny, Intercom).  
   • Track NPS and churn cohorts monthly.  
   • Maintain public roadmap/changelog for transparency.  
   • Release at steady cadence (weekly/bi-weekly).  
   • Automate crash/error reporting (Sentry, Rollbar).  

10. Scale responsibly  
   • Optimize infrastructure only after proof of demand.  
   • Introduce feature flags, per-tenant throttling, read replicas.  
   • Split monolith when necessary (modularize first).  
   • Document code and ops; prepare on-call rotation.  

11. Grow revenue  
   • Up-sell: advanced features, extra seats, premium support, training.  
   • Cross-sell: complementary tools or add-on modules.  
   • Geo-expand: translate UI, local payment methods.  
   • Enterprise tier: SLAs, SSO/SAML, dedicated account manager.  

12. Exit options (long term)  
   • Lifestyle business (owner operated, steady dividends).  
   • Acquisition (strategic buyer, PE roll-up, acqui-hire).  
   • Scale + raise VC (if market is huge and you want hyper-growth).  

Quick starter checklist  
[ ] Proof people will pay for solution  
[ ] Clear MLP spec and tech stack  
[ ] Payment, auth and analytics integrated  
[ ] Legal docs and tax settings live  
[ ] Wait-list + beta users engaged  
[ ] Launch assets: landing page, demo video, press kit  
[ ] Support channels staffed  
[ ] Iteration calendar set

Remember: success rarely comes from the most lines of code; it comes from the tightest loop between customer pain, delivered value, and refined messaging. Ship, learn, repeat—and you’ll turn software into a real, sellable product.
